dt: {bc}to {d_link|depreciate|depreciate} (something, such as a coin) officially or publicly

dt.t: the king may at any time {wi}decry{/wi} … any coin of the kingdom
… has {wi}decried{/wi} the medical marijuana ballot initiative as being rife with loopholes.

pt: {sc}decry{/sc} {sc}depreciate{/sc} {sc}disparage{/sc} {sc}belittle{/sc} mean to express a low opinion of. {sc}decry{/sc} implies open condemnation with intent to discredit.
{sc}depreciate{/sc} implies a representing as being of less value than commonly believed.

pt.t: critics {it}depreciate{/it} his plays for being unabashedly sentimental

pt: {sc}disparage{/sc} implies depreciation by indirect means such as slighting or invidious comparison.

pt.t: {it}disparaged{/it} polo as a game for the rich

pt: {sc}belittle{/sc} usually suggests a contemptuous or envious attitude.

et: borrowed from French {it}décrier{/it} "to discredit, depreciate," going back to Middle French {it}descrier{/it} (15th century), from {it}des-{/it} {et_link|de-|de-} + {it}crier{/it} "to {et_link|cry:1|cry:1}"

A supposed 13th-century French usage of {it}descrier{/it} in the sense "to announce (the depreciation or suppression of a currency)," mentioned without citation in the {it}Französisches etymologisches Wörterbuch,{/it} has never been found and should probably be disregarded. See also note at {et_link|descry:1|descry:1}.
shortdef: to depreciate (something, such as a coin) officially or publicly
